instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01598: What is 820-01598? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A2159: What is A2159? A2159 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3301, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01598..
definitions.PP3V3_S0SW_LCD: What is PP3V3_S0SW_LCD? PP3V3_S0SW_LCD is a 3.3v power rail necessary to power the image circuitry on the screen. This is necessary to get a picture on the screen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Issues
threads.message:
Working on an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2159</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>) that came in with physical damage to the LCD assembly near the hinge/screen bevel (see attached).
The board itself appears pristine with no signs of corrosion or liquid damage.  
Tested with known good LCD assembly and the backlight is still out. 

Measurements so far (bare board):

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SOSW_LCD</SIGNAL> --- 5V
F8400 --- 12v, 0Ω
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> --- 3.3V
<DIODE>D8410</DIODE> pin 1 --- 5V
<DIODE>D8410</DIODE> pin 2 --- ~33mV
EPD lines from J8500 all appear to be good, no shorts to ground. 

It seems the backlight circuit for these is significantly more complex than for previous models. [URL='https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-from-hell-backlight-problems.60710/']This thread[/URL] may have been a similar issue, but it was never resolved. 

Any advice would be greatly appreciated. 


[ATTACH type="full"]60192[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Issues
threads.message:
"Measurements so far (bare board)"
Did you measure backlight area without LCD connected???

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Issues
threads.message:
That I did! 

With the LCD connected measurements are as follows:

<SIGNAL>PP5V_SOSW_LCD</SIGNAL> --- 5V
F8400 --- 12.7v, 0Ω
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_LCD</SIGNAL> --- 3.3V
<DIODE>D8410</DIODE> pin 1 --- 0.2V
<DIODE>D8410</DIODE> pin 2 --- ~0V
EPD lines from J8500 all appear to be good, no shorts to ground.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Issues
threads.message:
I checked <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> as it's the next thing upstream from <DIODE>D8400</DIODE> which was the only component that appeared different.

<TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR>

pin1: 0V
pin2: 0V
pin3: 12.6V
pin4: 12.6V
pin5: 0V
pin6: 0V

Looking at <CAPACITOR>C8410</CAPACITOR> i'm getting 0V from <SIGNAL>PPV_S0SW_LCDBKLT</SIGNAL>, and <CAPACITOR>C8401</CAPACITOR> is running at about 0.5V on both pins.

Am I on the right track here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Issues
threads.message:
First, I can't find <TRANSISTOR>Q8410</TRANSISTOR> in schematic.
The 6 pins violtage don't match with <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR>, nor <TRANSISTOR>Q8401</TRANSISTOR>.
Please post accurate information!

BTW, ALWAYS check video/backlight related voltage/signal ONLY with LCD connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Issues
threads.message: Sorry, fixed the typo in the post. Those were the measured voltages from the 6 pin <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR>.[ATTACH type="full"]60195[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01598</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Backlight Issues
threads.message:
As per shematic, pins 1, 2, 5, 6 are tied together.
You can compare with any similar SOT23-6 MOSFET.
Please, post CORRECT information!
